results.title: [5 Couleurs de France]
results.brief_description:
This film is a TV Color Paris production titled ‘5 Couleurs de France’, which translates as ‘5 Colours of France’. It features a presentation on the 1967 Cannes Film Festival, with a voiceover spoken in English. The 1967 festival was the 20th anniversary of the festival. The film includes snippets of interviews with Claude Lelouche, Sylva Koscina, Robert Bresson, Monica Vitti and Vanessa Redgrave, translated by the narrator.

It also contains footage of film stars and directors at the festival, particularly at the awards ceremony. These include guest of honour Brigitte Bardot, award presenter Virna Lisi and winner of the Palme d’Or (then known as the Grand Prix International du Festival) Michelangelo Antonioni, for his film ‘Blow Up’.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

results.title: ....And everything nice
results.creator_credit: Columbia Broadcasting System and Norma Adams
results.brief_description: Through the process of consciousness raising, women develop new expectations for themselves and a sense of self-worth. The process is marked by an understanding of the ways in which society teaches women to assume passive roles in directing their own lives. In asserting themselves for the first time, many women experience fears and conflicts about the future of women as members of society.

results.title: (dis)LOCATIONs symposium
results.creator_credit: Jeffrey Shaw, Dennis Del Favero, Peter Weibel and Anna Munster
results.brief_description:
A conference about fragmentation of ‘community’, urbanisation and the collapse of locale and neighbourhood, the erosion of the private spaces of the sexual and familial. These have emerged as thematics attributable to the restructuring and divergent flows of new information economies and mediascapes.

Featuring key note speakers including Jeffrey Shaw, Dennis Del Favero, Agnes Hegedus, Susan Norrie, Peter Weibel, Ursula Frohne, Lev Manovich.

results.title: #AllMyMovies
results.creator_credit: Nastja Säde Rönkkö and Shia LaBeouf

constellations_other.name: Now watch this
constellations_other.description: In a video-saturated world, how do you keep focus? Do you keep a close eye on one thing, or step back and watch the parade of images go by, to see the whole thing?

results.description: LaBeouf, Rönkkö and Turner invited the public to join Shia LaBeouf as he watched all his movies, consecutively in reverse chronological order over the course of three days, 24 hours a day, with the performance continuously broadcast online.
description_for_label: LaBeouf, Rönkkö and Turner invited the public to join Shia LaBeouf as he watched all his movies, consecutively in reverse chronological order over the course of three days, 24 hours a day, with the performance continuously broadcast online.

results.title: !OINK
results.creator_credit: Ruth Fleishman and Victoria University EDIM
results.brief_description: An interactive adaptation of a novel by Melbourne writer Eric Dando, !OINK is an exploration through various stages of life of Squirly Fern. We travel into the details of his life as he tries to find a place for himself in a world of the post-human step family animal/human genetic engineering; alien prototype inventions; corporate ownership od sleep and awake states and technology as a spiritual saviour.

results.title: Prosthetic Transformations
results.brief_description: Odd Studio turn a young woman into a witch through prosthetics and makeup, in process that involves sketching, sculpting, blasting, plastering and painting a variety of materials like silicone, alginate and clay into replicas and moulds that transform actors.

constellations_primary.name: Oscar-winning transformations and prosthetics
constellations_primary.description: This Constellation explores how craft help actors undergo award-winning transformations into iconic characters.

results.description:
There’s a joke that actors who want to win an Oscar should dramatically transform their physical appearance. Picture Nicole Kidman, unrecognisable as Virginia Woolf in her Oscar-winning role in The Hours (2002), or Heath Ledger, who was posthumously awarded an Academy Award for playing the savagely scarred Joker in The Dark Knight (2008). Those iconic transformations are all done through extensive makeup and hairstyling coupled with prosthetics, like the kind that Australian company Odd Studio used to win an Oscar for their work on Mad Max: Fury Road (2015).  

Here Odd Studio demonstrate their skills by turning a young woman into a witch. The process involves sketching, sculpting, blasting, plastering and painting a variety of materials like silicone, alginate and clay into replicas and moulds that transform actors into all variety of shapes, faces and features.
description_for_label:
There’s a joke that actors who want to win an Oscar should dramatically transform their physical appearance. Picture Nicole Kidman, unrecognisable as Virginia Woolf in her Oscar-winning role in The Hours (2002), or Heath Ledger, who was posthumously awarded an Academy Award for playing the savagely scarred Joker in The Dark Knight (2008). Those iconic transformations are all done through extensive makeup and hairstyling coupled with prosthetics, like the kind that Australian company Odd Studio used to win an Oscar for their work on Mad Max: Fury Road (2015).  

Here Odd Studio demonstrate their skills by turning a young woman into a witch. The process involves sketching, sculpting, blasting, plastering and painting a variety of materials like silicone, alginate and clay into replicas and moulds that transform actors into all variety of shapes, faces and features.
